title-group.article-title: Monotonicity of the Stochastic Discount Factor and Expected Option Returns

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright © 2015 The Society for Financial Studies

abstract.p: Evidence shows that the stochastic discount factor (SDF) is not always a downward-sloping function of S&P 500 returns when estimated using options data. In contrast, our results suggest that SDFs as functions of individual stock returns are generally downward sloping. A simple jump-diffusion model can reconcile these empirical findings. The same model also implies a steeper implied-volatility curve for the index than for the typical stock, a well-known empirical fact from the options literature. Both the SDF and volatility-curve results can be explained by a common source of jump risk among stocks, together with diversification of Brownian risk in the index. We also devise novel empirical tests of SDF monotonicity based on average returns of option trading strategies, thus avoiding the estimation of the return density functions.

p.mixed-citation: A bullish call spread is long a call at one strike price and short a call at a higher strike price, with both options on the same stock and with the same expiration.

Explanations for nonmonotonicity include nontraded income or state variables (Brown and Jackwerth 2004); state dependence in the representative agent's utility (Brown and Jackwerth 2004); heterogeneous investor beliefs (Ziegler 2007; Bakshi and Madan 2009; and Hens and Reichlin 2013); the influence of a latent state variable (Chabi-Yo, Garcia, and Renault 2008); Epstein-Zin preferences and a persistent state variable subject to jumps (Benzoni, Collin-Dufresne, and Goldstein 2011); negative variance risk premium (Christoffersen, Heston, and Jacobs 2013); and investor sentiment (Han 2008). There is some contradictory evidence. For example, Barone-Adesi and Dall'O (2012)'s findings support strict monotonicity.
The "rate of compensation" in our context is defined as the market price of risk per unit return.

More precisely, the left-hand and right-hand derivatives of ln(g()) (which exist by concavity) are strictly decreasing. Concave functions are differentiable (the left and right-hand derivatives are the same) almost everywhere.

Although the case of butterfly spreads (as well as call options) suggests a link to skewness, we emphasize that a (first-order dominance) shift to the right in payouts does not imply, nor is implied by, an increase in skewness. For example, vanilla and binary put options both have log-concave payouts and, therefore, expected returns increasing in strike, but the skewness of returns of both typically decreases as the strike increases.
The proof can be provided upon request. It is essentially the same as the sufficiency part of the proof of Proposition 1 after replacing g'/g with ~pk/P-

More precisely, we follow the CBOE strike-increment rule and remove those stock-week combinations for which the absolute difference between the current stock price and nearest strike is $2.5 or higher when current stock prices are $25 or less, $5 or higher when the stock price is $25 through $200, and $10 or higher when the stock price is over $200. There are 559 such cases (on average, less than one occurrence a week) which represents less than 0.1 % of our final sample.

If a particular option price is missing or does not satisfy the no-arbitrage restriction, then the associated return differences are considered as missing. For example if the strike group 2 return for a stock on a particular week is missing, then we assign the return differences "2— l"and "3-2" as missing.

Rejection of monotonicity based on unconditional returns would imply rejection with conditional returns (a conditional expectation cannot be a.s. positive if the expectation is negative). However, with sufficient data, a stricter test of monotonicity could be designed when unconditional expectations are found to be strictly positive. Nevertheless, in our jump-diffiision model, with returns modeled as a Levy process, the projected SDF and the option-strategy returns do not depend on any state variables, and the "conditioning down" has no effect.
Broadie et al. (2009) also argue that care must be taken when assessing the performance of option returns because of their high skewness.

As one indication, using her sorting rule, the average elasticity for her deep OTM calls is smaller than that for the At-the-Money (ATM) group, even though Black-Scholes elasticities are monotonically increasing in strike, ceteris paribus. One explanation for this is that her sorting rule results in assigning a disproportionate number of low priced, and, consequently, significantly higher volatility stocks to higher strike groups. In the Black-Scholes model, for example, the elasticity of a call option, and therefore the call-option expected return, decreases with volatility. This causes her deep OTM calls to have lower average returns than those of the ATM calls. Detailed tables illustrating these results can be provided upon request.

The assumption p >0 is without loss of generality (we can always reverse the signs Bc) we assume a' > 0 for simplicity, so that each stock has positive per-unit-return market price of systematic Brownian risk.
See also Das and Uppal (2004), who consider a common jump model in an international setting and its effect on portfolio choice.

In the Ito expansion of the state-price density, ln(X/A.) is the coefficient of dNt, and — rf is the coefficient of dBf. Because the state-price density in this model is strictly positive, the model is arbitrage free.
That is, there exist constants y,e> 0 such that K -4tto(K)— <yyfx for all r

If X > A. but stock i's price increases at market crashes ({/1 > 0), then Sl > 0 necessarily holds because the positive crash reward (instead of a negative Brownian reward) is associated with returns above yfr' /2.

Bakshi and Wu (201 l)'s diffusion risk coefficient (which, in their setting, is the negative of the state-price-density coefficient of dBf times the stock volatility) is estimated to be 1.82, which must be multiplied by a =0.30 to obtain our rf.
See also Branger and others (2008). They show, using simulations, that diversification of the idiosyncratic component of stochastic volatility produces steeper implied slopes for indexes.

The ATM slope for each stock is calculated by first finding the two strikes nearest to the money, and then computing the ratio of the difference in the two implied volatilities to the difference in the two strikes. Our results are insensitive to the normalization. We get similar results if we sort based on the slope measure n instead.

The betas, /?, and RMSE are estimated for each underlying stock and each month from the Fama-French and Carhart 4-factor regression model using daily returns. Similar results are obtained using just the CAPM or Fama-French 3 factor model

Stocks with market capitalization less than $1 billion are classified as small cap, $1 billion to $5 billion as midcap, and greater than $5 billion as large cap. Market-to-book ratios are calculated using definitions provided on Kenneth French's website, and we use trading volume of the underlying stock on the buying date of the option strategy as a proxy for liquidity. Firms are classified as financials if their SIC codes are between 6000 and 6999.
To apply the lemma, define Y=m{Sj), and the decreasing function f(Y)= 1 (K)^.
As another example, if Jj = riy=i Vj where {Vj; j = 1,2,...) are i.i.d., then In J Ë (/{ j | =XË(V — 1).
It is well known that put-call parity implies that the implied volatilities for European calls and puts are identical.
Although, our focus is on testing monotonically increasing alternatives, this test, in principle, can be modified to test other patterned alternatives (for example, U-shaped kernels).
Unlike the Spearman rank correlation test, the Page test allows dependence among each time-/ set of observations.
Equally likely ranks implies Var(Lt)=-i-0:+l)2(fc —1), which yields the classical Page statistic.

A special case is if each permutation is equally likely (as in the classical Page test). Another special case is if the distribution of the rank is symmetric under Hq in the sense that the distribution of (xj,...xf^ is the same as the distribution ^xf,...xj^j, which includes the case of only two equally likely rankings: strictly ascending or strictly descending.

Closely related to Page is the test of Bathke (2009), which is Equation (Dl) but with X replaced by Y in the definition of Lt, where (y^denotes the length-T k vector of ranks of the entire sample of average returns across time and strikes (which is some permutation of {1,..., T • k}). That is, the Page test is based on the per-period ranks of average returns, whereas the Bathke (2009) test is based on the overall average ranks. The assumptions for asymptotic standard normality of B under the null are therefore stronger. In particular, Bathke (2009) assumes that the average return vectors are i.i.d. over time. Heteroscedasticity is likely to be more of a problem with the Bathke (2009) tests because, for example, increasing variance over time is likely to result in more extreme ranks appearing later in the sample, giving more weight to those observations.
We thank Andrew Patton for providing the MATLAB code for the stationary bootstrap on his website.
